Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: List of heterogenenous array: :I am a "Java noob", so be patient with me :)I need to create a particular structure that contains heterogeneous fields. I'm getting the Android.Location from a GPS device (my smartphone) and I want to store all the Locations, but I need to add to each of them some other fields. So, my structure will be something like that:[0]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[1]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[2]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[3]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[4]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String...[n]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - StringI don't know the number of "rows" because it depends on some variables (like time, route, etc).Which is the best way to make it in Java?UPDATEIs it correct this solution?public Class LocationPlus {    private Location location;    private String string1;    private int int1;    private String string2;    private int int2;    // Constructor, setters, getters}Then, in my main:List<LocationPlus> locationPlus = new ArrayList<LocationPlus>();locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “marco”, 1, “bianco”, 2));locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “luca”, 3, “arancio”, 4));locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “giovanni”, 5, “rossi”, 6));
Please using this api: List.get.
Answer:

Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: List of heterogenenous array: :I am a "Java noob", so be patient with me :)I need to create a particular structure that contains heterogeneous fields. I'm getting the Android.Location from a GPS device (my smartphone) and I want to store all the Locations, but I need to add to each of them some other fields. So, my structure will be something like that:[0]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[1]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[2]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[3]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String[4]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - String...[n]: Location - String - int - String - int - String - StringI don't know the number of "rows" because it depends on some variables (like time, route, etc).Which is the best way to make it in Java?UPDATEIs it correct this solution?public Class LocationPlus {    private Location location;    private String string1;    private int int1;    private String string2;    private int int2;    // Constructor, setters, getters}Then, in my main:List<LocationPlus> locationPlus = new ArrayList<LocationPlus>();locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “marco”, 1, “bianco”, 2));locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “luca”, 3, “arancio”, 4));locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “giovanni”, 5, “rossi”, 6));
Please using this api: List.get.
Answer:<<<api>>>: List.get
<<<code>>>: List<LocationPlus> locationPlus = new ArrayList<LocationPlus>();
locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “marco”, 1, “bianco”, 2));
locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “luca”, 3, “arancio”, 4));
locationPlus.add(new LocationPlus(location, “giovanni”, 5, “rossi”, 6));
LocationPlus locationPlus = locationPlus.get(0);
<<<explanation>>>: The get() method of the List interface returns the element at the specified position in this list. This is a terminal operation.
Question: How can I get the current time in Java?
Please using this api: LocalDateTime.now.
Answer:<<<api>>>: LocalDateTime.now
<<<code>>>: LocalDateTime now = LocalDateTime.now();
<<<explanation>>>: The now() method of the LocalDateTime class returns the current date-time using the system clock and the default time-zone. This is a static factory method. This is a terminal operation.
Question: How can I get the current time in Java?
Please using this api: Calendar.getInstance.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Calendar.getInstance
<<<code>>>: Calendar calendar = Calendar.getInstance();
<<<explanation>>>: The getInstance() method of the Calendar class returns a Calendar object whose calendar fields have been initialized with the current date and time. This is a static factory method. This is a terminal operation.
Question: How can I get the current time in Java?
Please using this api: System.currentTimeMillis.
Answer:<<<api>>>: System.currentTimeMillis
<<<code>>>: long currentTimeMillis = System.currentTimeMillis();
<<<explanation>>>: The currentTimeMillis() method of the System class returns the current time in milliseconds. This is a static factory method. This is a terminal operation.
Question: How can I get the current time in Java?
Please using this api: System.nanoTime.
Answer:<<<api>>>: System.nanoTime
<<<code>>>: long nanoTime = System.nanoTime();
<<<explanation>>>: The nanoTime() method of the System class returns the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds. This is a static factory method. This is a terminal operation.
